Smart Move.

With a 4500-pound tow rating just for boats, the Acura MDX does the thinking for you

The MDX is the first Acura I have tested, simply because the company did not have anything in the past that would merit a tow test. However, this new sport-utility vehicle (SUV) piqued my interest well before the test, due to its unique split tow ratings. When towing fixed-sided trailers, such as box trailers, it is rated for 3500 pounds. For trailered boats, however, the MDX is rated for 4500 pounds (see Jim Hendricks' "On Plane," on page 10).

Having now put the MDX through a rigorous tow test, I can say that it is one of the most impressive SUVs ever built. I am particularly impressed with the automatic transmission/engine combination that does all the towing work usually performed by the driver, and a suspension that delivers excellent towing and non-towing stability at all speeds.

Sized similarly to the Ford Explorer, the MDX has a versatile, seven-passenger interior, with second- and third-row seats. The seats split and fold flat into the floor to accommodate a variety of passenger and cargo-carrying configurations.

The vehicle's offroad capabilities are considered to be medium-duty, without the extra, overwhelmingly beefy components that detract from on-road performance. However, the MDX comes with a deeper oil pan and a heavy-duty air filter for offroading. Waterproofing was also added to allow the MDX to traverse 18-inch-deep bodies of water. And the throttle linkage was calibrated to provide more sensitive control over engine output at low speeds. It also has a tight turning radius, making it easy to maneuver on twisty mountain roads and in tight parking lots.

Diminutive Dynamo

In case you are not familiar with Acura, it's built by American Honda, which has created some of the finest small power plants in the world, including racing engines. The MDX uses a 3.5L V-6. But don't be influenced by its diminutive displacement. It's a dynamite performer.

The all-aluminum, double-overhead camshaft (DOHC), 24-valve engine has a Variable Timing and Lift Electronic Control (VTEC) system. This allows the engine to produce 240 hp and 245 ft.-lbs. of torque. It delivers 95 percent of its peak torque (pulling power) from 2000 to 5500 rpm, which is excellent for towing.

The V-6 has low-restriction intake and exhaust systems, a 10:1 compression ratio (which requires premium fuel), and roller-type rocker arms. A lightweight, forged-steel crankshaft is used for maximum strength, rigidity and durability.

Most engines have fixed valve-train parameters -- the same timing for valve lift and overlap, regardless of whether the engine is struggling to climb out of a low-rpm range or screaming at redline. But Acura/Honda's VTEC approach has two distinct modes -- it changes intake-valve operation to optimize volumetric efficiency (breathing) and combustion of the fuel-air mixture. Depending on engine speed, the rocker arms are electronically shifted to either the high-speed or low-speed lobes of the camshaft to provide a different range of performance.

Benefits Of Vtec

During the towing acceleration tests, I quickly learned how well the VTEC system worked. The air/fuel intake did its job so adeptly that seeing the tachometer shoot up quickly was the only noticeable change. What made acceleration so impressive was that the towing times were very close to the speed when I was not towing -- only tenths of a second apart.

Unlike other small engines, the 3.5L V-6 wants to run at interstate speeds when towing, even up moderate hills, without prodding. I chose not to use fourth or fifth gears on the hills; both gears were too tall. But more surprises were in store.

Every time I decided to downshift on an uphill, the transmission beat me to it. After a few of these one-upmanships by the transmission, I decided it wasn't necessary to downshift, because the tranny was holding lower gears just as long as I would if I were shifting.

On flat ground at 55 and 65 mph, I tried using fourth-gear overdrive. The tach dropped to 2100 rpm. But, as I kept a watchful eye, it soon was up to 2400 rpm, then varied between 2400 and 2700 rpm, which is a normal difference between the transmission's lockup and unlock systems. Then, when the grades got steeper, I was reading 3300 rpm, with no feeling that it had dropped to third gear. I confirmed this by dropping the gearshift lever to third with no change in rpm. This was the VTEC and transmission playing their inconspicuous roles.

Dynamite Drivetrain

A five-speed, electronically controlled, automatic transmission is standard on all models. It's the new VTM-4 (Variable Torque Management 4WD) -- a fully automatic, four-wheel-drive system. And it works integrally with the engine.

When I first read about this wide-ratio, five-speed automatic, I expected lackluster towing performance because of the drop in engine speed on upshifts and the big burst of engine speed on downshifts. Not so.

Instead, the engine VTEC system "read" what was happening and corrected engine rpm before the transmission had a chance to balk, producing extremely smooth transitions between gears. The MDX is basically a front-wheel-drive vehicle (FWD), but you would never know it while driving.

Unlike other on-demand 4WD and all-wheel-drive (AWD) systems, the VTM-4 doesn't wait for slippage to happen. Instead, torque is delivered to the rear wheels in proportion to forward acceleration to supplement FWD. This has two advantages. First, on dry pavement, it is less likely to torque-steer (the tendency of the steering wheel to pull to one side during acceleration) and to provide more front-tire adhesion when cornering. In wet or snowy conditions, automatic AWD gets the vehicle moving with less chance of wheel-spin.

A button on the dash activates an exclusive lock feature. It allows the driver to send maximum torque (53 percent) to the rear wheels in extremely low-speed, low-traction or "stuck" situations. It works very well on launch ramps. The driver only needs to move the lever to one or more of the two lower forward gears or reverse, then touch a button on the dash. With the lock mode engaged, VTM-4 automatically reduces the transfer of torque to the rear axle at about 6 mph and reverts to front drive by 18 mph. When cruising, with no wheel-slip present, the system reverts to FWD for improved fuel economy.

Chassis

There was no bouncing or movement in the back of this vehicle when towing 4400 pounds with a light (240-pound) tongue weight. With the window open, I could hear the trailer bounce and make noise, but none of that action was being transferred to the tow vehicle.

To overcome the usual ride vs. handling compromises, especially with a rigid uni-body, the MDX uses front and rear subframes to isolate road noise and drivetrain vibration from the passenger compartment. This is a procedure many uni-body makers use.

These subframes house the front and rear suspension systems and provide extra wheel travel to complement the suspension. Low roll centers (for center of gravity) are combined with stiff anti-roll bars to provide progressive, predictable cornering response and excellent stability at the limit of adhesion. The rack-and-pinion steering has a very positive feel.

The MDX also has a wide track to maximize stability and cornering traction. The wide stance is said to be 2 1/2 to 4 3/4 inches wider than its closest competitor.

Braking Performance

To provide short stopping distances, fade-resistance and a reassuring pedal feel, the four-wheel disc-brake system uses large-diameter rotors and extra-rigid, single-piston calipers. The ABS features electronic distribution of brake force at all four wheels.

In our case, the MDX had an exceptional non-towing stop of 94 feet, without a flaw or pedal-throb. And thanks to the trailer's Trailer Buddy brakes, braking when towing from 55 mph was only 116 feet -- very good for a 4400-pound load and mid-size SUV.

Incidentally, for towing, Acura requires a dealer-installed transmission cooler for the MDX. Factory hitches and trailer wiring are also available.

In the final analysis, the MDX came as a pleasant surprise. It provides good visibility, exceptional seating comfort, crisp handling, surprising performance and handles its maximum tow rating for boats very well.

If there is any negative, it is the price -- $38,970. This includes a $2600 touring package -- seat and mirror memory system, eight-way power-adjustable passenger seat, roof rack, upgraded sound system with CD - and a $2000 navigation system.

Kovacik, Bob
Trailer Boats
February 1, 2001
